title: 1: How To Learn Spanish Fluently
description: Learn Spanish, step by step! Welcome to LearnCraft Spanish, a proven system that will teach you how to learn Spanish fluently. Starting with a foundation of core Spanish grammar and the most common Spanish vocabulary, Timothy will guide you through the essential steps to speaking and understanding fluent Spanish like a native speaker. If you're a serious Spanish learner and you want to make deep, personal connections with the native Spanish speakers in your life, the LearnCraft Spanish podcast is for you. Join us on a rigorous, fulfilling journey to Spanish fluency.

title: 2: Core Spanish Grammar for Fluency
description: What’s the key to speaking Spanish fluently, spontaneously, and effortlessly? Mastering core Spanish grammar. To learn how to speak Spanish fluently, we need to start by mastering the structures and elements that make Spanish different from English. Today we’ll learn some essential Spanish grammar and do some spoken grammar exercises to make it stick. After this foundational work, Spanish grammar will get easier and easier — and Spanish fluency will be all downhill!

title: 3: The Words That Will Make You Fluent in Spanish
description: To become fluent in Spanish, you have to learn connecting words! Today we’re talking about conjunctions, particularly the words que and y, and how they help hold the whole Spanish language together and create fluent flow. We’ll also learn why conjunctions are even more important in Spanish than in English, based on a special rule about Spanish verbs. After this episode, you’ll know how to use the most common word in the Spanish language, getting you one step closer to thinking in Spanish.

title: 4: Learn these 3 Spanish Words To Start Thinking in Spanish
description: Some Spanish words are more important than others! In today’s episode, we will talk about how you can start *thinking* in Spanish by choosing the right words to work on. We will focus on some of the highest-leverage words in the language — three words that comprise 8% of the Spanish language by themselves. After we practice with these words, you’ll soon be able to start forming sentences like a native Spanish speaker. For show notes, transcript, and free practice materials, visit https://LCSPodcast.com/4

title: 5: Spanish Quizzing and the Testing Effect
description: Time to practice your Spanish out loud! Today we’ll learn about the number one way to solidify a new language in your brain — and we’ll get to put it into practice right away. If you follow this one tip, you’ll be fluent in Spanish faster than you ever thought possible. Let’s put everything we’ve learned so far into Spanish practice, out loud.

title: 6: Spanish Pronunciation Tips
description: To learn fluent Spanish, you can’t just memorize words — you also have to master Spanish pronunciation. Today I present my top tips for pronouncing Spanish sounds authentically. Here’s the first tip: To develop your own “Spanish voice”, make sure to do the pronunciation exercises, out loud, throughout this episode!

title: 7: What does “lo” mean in Spanish?
description: The Spanish word “lo” is usually a HUGE headache for English speakers — but it won’t be for you! You’ll be using “lo” and “la” correctly after listening to this episode. Let’s get some good, active practice with the words for “him” and “her” in Spanish.

title: 8: Spanish Pronouns and Memory Palaces
description: Why are Spanish direct object pronouns different from other pronouns? And how can you keep from mixing up all the different Spanish pronouns? Let’s use a memory palace to keep all of our Spanish pronouns straight. We’ll work on the Spanish pronouns for “him”, “her”, “me”, and “you”, and then we’ll put it all into practice with real sentences.

title: 9: Por vs Para
description: Let’s learn por and para. These words tend to be very hard to master when learning Spanish as a second language, but today we’ll learn a simple framework that you can use to decide between these two words in almost any context. https://LCSPodcast.com/9

title: 10: How to say “them” in Spanish
description: The word “them” may seem like a basic word, but it has multiple translations in Spanish! Today we’ll learn two Spanish words for “them”, as well as the word for “what”. We’ll also get lots of spoken practice with all of our essential Spanish vocabulary. https://LCSPodcast.com/10

title: 11: How to express concepts in Spanish
description: Learn Spanish faster by starting with the hard stuff — like expressing concepts! In this episode, we’ll lay the groundwork for expressing abstract ideas, concepts, and thoughts in fluent Spanish… and it all starts by mastering the #1 most important word in the Spanish language.

title: 12: What Is “Is” in Spanish?
description: How do you say “is” in Spanish? It MIGHT be the word “es”... and it might not! Let’s learn our first conjugation of Ser, and we’ll explore when you might use this word. This is the most common verb in Spanish, and the most common conjugation (by far). Today we’ll get some practice with “es” in a lot of sentence contexts.

title: 13: How to conjugate Ser
description: Spanish Conjugations can be tough… but they don’t have to be! Let’s learn the present tense forms of Ser using a memory palace.

title: 14: Why do Spanish subject pronouns “disappear”?
description: Why does Spanish let you start a sentence with “soy” or “son” — without “yo” or “ellos”? And how can you tell when you should include the subject pronoun or leave it out? Let’s practice the skill of choosing whether or not to use subject pronouns with Spanish verbs.

title: 15: Practice Ser (and everything else!)
description: Let’s practice our present-tense conjugations of Ser, as well as everything we’ve learned in this podcast so far! Quiz the Spanish out loud to help make all of this grammar second-nature.

title: 16: Why Ser is so common
description: The Spanish verb Ser doesn’t strictly mean “to be”; it means something much more specific. But it’s used in a wide variety of ways! Let’s learn how to think in Spanish by “thinking in Ser”, and using Ser to express identity in many different ways.

title: 17: Spanish subject pronouns
description: Learn Spanish subject pronouns, such as él, ella, nosotros, and yo, using a memory palace! After learning how to say the Spanish words for “he”, “she”, “I”, etc., you’ll be able to form a lot of sentences entirely in Spanish.

title: 18: Ser, past tense conjugations
description: Let’s learn the past-tense forms of Ser, using a memory palace! Today we’ll also discuss our 3-step method for learning Spanish verb conjugations so that you can use them fluently.

title: 19: Ser: Advanced Use as a Linking Verb
description: The verb Ser is used in a lot of complex ways. Let’s practice some new sentence templates for this linking verb as we become more and more fluent with our present and past conjugations of Ser.

title: 20: Spanish fluency, after a lifetime of trying!
description: Mike became fluent in Spanish after a lifetime of trying — in this episode we’ll talk about how he did it, and we’ll practice all of the Spanish skills we’ve learned up to this point with a comprehensive quiz.

title: 21: How to use “usted” in Spanish
description: Usted vs tú: Why are there two words for “you” in Spanish? Today we’ll learn how to use usted and practice it in a bunch of Spanish sentence contexts.

title: 22: Estar (and the magic wands)
description: Learn the Spanish verb Estar, using a memory palace! We’ll also talk about some ways you can use this “to be” verb, in contrast with how we’ve been using Ser.

title: 23: Estar’s stabby past tense
description: Time for the past tense of Estar! Learn and practice estaba, estabas, and the other imperfect past forms of Estar. We’ll also work on some advanced uses of Estar, including how to use this linking verb at the end of a sentence.

title: 24: Ser vs Estar Spanish Practice
description: Ser and Estar both translate as “to be” in English, but as you now know, the translation isn’t perfect! Let’s practice choosing the right verb, and the right conjugation, using some serious Spanish quizzing.

title: 25: Practice Ser and Estar
description: Let’s practice Ser, Estar, and all the essential Spanish we’ve learned.

title: 26: How To Use Subjunctives in Spanish
description: Spanish subjunctives don’t have to be hard! Let’s learn the most common uses of Spanish subjunctives to indicate intention. We’ll get lots of practice using the subjunctives of Ser and Estar in a variety of sentences.

title: 27: Using Subjunctive to Express Concepts in Spanish
description: Spanish subjunctives are often used to express abstract concepts such as intentions and emotions. Let’s learn some sentence templates for this, and we’ll practice them using the subjunctives of Ser and Estar.

title: 28: Mi, tu, su: Spanish possessive adjectives
description: Let’s learn how to use “mi”, “su”, “tu”, and “nuestro” before Spanish nouns. We’ll also get some practice with new conjunctions, including “pero” and “cuando”.

title: 29: El que, lo que, and la que
description: How do you use “lo que” in Spanish, without confusing it with “el que” and “la que”? And when should you use “qué” instead? Let’s dive into all the ways you can say “what” and “the one that” in Spanish. We’ll also learn how to use bueno and bien.

title: 30: How Eric became fluent in Spanish
description: Eric has wanted to learn Spanish his whole life. And now, with a Spanish-speaking partner and plans to move to Spain, Spanish fluency is no longer optional! Here is his story.

title: 31: Spanish Preterite vs Imperfect Past
description: Why does Spanish have two past tenses — the preterite and the imperfect? And how do you know which one to use in real life? Let’s explore the preterite and imperfect tenses, and we’ll also get some great practice using estaba, estuve, and estuvo.

title: 32: Será, Sería, Sido, Siendo
description: Let’s learn the last of our important conjugations of Ser, and we’ll get some good practice with the unconjugated forms ser, sido, and siendo.

title: 33: Estar, our last few forms!
description: Let’s wrap up learning Estar by working on estará, estaría, estarían, estarías, estaríamos, and estado.

title: 34: This thing, that thing // Do all Spanish nouns have a gender?
description: Esta, esto, este… esa, eso, and ese… let’s learn all the words for “this” and “that”. We’ll also talk about why some pronouns don’t have a grammatical gender, even though all nouns in Spanish are either masculine or feminine.

title: 34: This thing, that thing // Do all Spanish nouns have a gender?
description: Esta, esto, este… esa, eso, and ese… let’s learn all the words for “this” and “that”. We’ll also talk about why some pronouns don’t have a grammatical gender, even though all nouns in Spanish are either masculine or feminine.

title: 35: Practicing Ser and Estar, in all tenses
description: Let’s get lots of quizzing practice with Ser and Estar, in every commonly used tense and mood! We’ll also learn the prepositions del and al.

title: 37: Algo, nada, todo, and les
description: Let’s learn a lot more Spanish pronouns, including indirect objects, as well as the words for “something”, “nothing”, and “everything”.

title: 38: Hacer, hecho, and haciendo
description: Let’s learn how to use the words hacer, hecho, and haciendo in Spanish.

title: 39: Ya vs ahora
description: How do you say “now” in Spanish? Today we’ll explore a bunch of Spanish adverbs, including the words “ahora” and “ya”, the two different ways you can say “now”. We’ll also talk about some of the many ways “ya” can be translated into English.

title: 40: Conmigo, contigo, and Spanish prepositional pronouns
description: Prepositional pronouns let us do a lot of creative things in Spanish! Let’s learn how to say things like “with him”, “with her”, “for them”, and “from us” in Spanish.

title: 41: Spanish complex tenses
description: The past of the past? The continuous future? What is the purpose of complex verb phrases such as habías hecho and estará haciendo? Let’s learn how to do fun, complex things with verb tenses.

title: 42: Ir
description: Let’s learn how to say “go” in Spanish! We’ll learn the present-tense conjugations of Ir (voy, va, vas, van, and vamos), using a memory palace.

title: 43: How to put any Spanish verb in the future
description: Let’s learn how to use Ir to mean “going to”. This is how we can put any verb in the future, simply by using our conjugations of Ir along with an infinitive.

title: 44: How to conjugate Ir in Spanish
description: The verb Ir is one of the most irregular verbs in Spanish. Let’s learn its many conjugations, including the preterite, the subjunctive, and the future tense, using a memory palace.

title: 45: Practice Ir Out Loud
description: Use this quiz to practice using the Spanish verb Ir in all kinds of different ways — the present, the preterite, the imperfect, the future, and the subjunctive. Try to predict each Spanish sentence and speak out loud!

title: 46: Reflexive pronouns and Irse
description: Spanish reflexive pronouns are tricky, and they have many different uses! Let’s learn how to use se, me, te, and nos, especially when they turn Ir (“to go”) into Irse (“to leave”).

title: 47: Señor, verdad, and vida
description: Let’s learn 10 common Spanish nouns — including the words for “life”, “truth”, “woman”, and “man”, as well as the idioms for “actually” and “really”.

title: 48: Hay and greetings
description: Buenos días, buenas tardes, buenas noches! In this episode we’ll cover some essential greetings and polite terms in Spanish, such as gracias and de nada. We’ll also discuss how to use Haber to talk about existence, using words like hay and había.

title: 49 : Spanish Adverbs
description: Where, when, how, and how much? Let’s learn how to ask some common questions in Spanish, as well as the adverbs you can use to answer them!

title: 50: Idioms
description: Sometimes words don’t mean what they seem to mean! Let’s use our Spanish vocabulary to create new meanings by combining them into non-literal phrases we call idioms — such as ya que and ya está.

title: 51: Tener
description: Tener and Haber are the two ways to say “have” in Spanish. Let’s start learning Tener and practice using the present tense conjugations (tengo, tiene, tienes, tienen, and tenemos).

title: 52: How to say “had” in Spanish
description: The Spanish verb Tener has a lot of conjugations — let’s learn the many ways this verb is used, including the preterite, imperfect past tense, future, and subjunctive. We’ll also get a lot of spoken practice using Tener in context.

title: 53: How to express obligation in Spanish
description: How do you use Tener and Haber to talk about obligations, such as “I had to do that” and “someone needs to do it”? Let’s explore the Tener + que and Haber + que constructions that Spanish uses to express obligation.

title: 54: Spanish imperatives
description: Spanish imperatives can be tricky, especially some of the most-used imperatives such as ve, ten, and váyase. Let’s learn both the positive and negative imperatives of Ir, Irse, and Tener — and get lots of practice using them in context.

title: 55: Spanish Imperative Practice
description: Let’s practice using Spanish imperatives out loud! Here’s a spoken quiz to give you a variety of ways to practice imperative terms such as vete, váyase, ten, and tenga

title: 56: The Spanish personal “a”
description: Why does the Spanish preposition “a” appear right before some direct objects? Let’s practice using the personal “a” in Spanish sentences. We’ll also learn a couple of new idioms involving other Spanish prepositions.

title: 57: Ser, the preterite tense
description: How do you use fui, fue, fuiste, fueron, and fuimos as forms of Ser? Let’s learn how to use Ser’s preterite tense — which looks and sounds exactly like the preterite tense of Ir!

title: 58: Fuera and other past tense subjunctives
description: Why does Spanish have a past tense subjunctive — and will you ever need it? Let’s learn how to use fuera, estuviera, and tuviera.

title: 59: Porque and Hasta
description: What’s the difference between “because” and “because of” in Spanish? Let’s talk about porque versus por, as well as the several different meanings of hasta.

title: 60: Practice fue, fui, and fuera
description: Today we’ll get lots of out-loud practice with some of the trickiest forms of Ser and Ir, such as fue, fui, fuiste, fueron, fuimos, and fuera. We’ll also learn some new ways that you can use todo.

title: 61: Hacer - “to do” or “to make”
description: The Spanish verb Hacer means both “to do” and “to make”. Let’s practice its present-tense forms, hago, hace, haces, hacen, and hacemos, as well as the unconjugated forms. We’ll also practice Hacerse, which roughly means “to become”.

title: 62: How to conjugate Hacer
description: Let’s learn the rest of the essential forms of Hacer, including the imperfect past (such as hacía), the preterite (such as hice), the future (such as haré), and the subjunctive (such as haga). We’ll also explore verb contractions, such as hacerlo and hazlo.

title: 63: Redundant Indirect Objects
description: Why does Spanish use the phrases “se lo” and “se la” so often? And when does le turn into se? Let’s explore some advanced uses of Spanish indirect objects. We’ll also get lots of practice using the “redundant a” and putting our object pronouns in the right order in Spanish sentences.

title: 64: Problema, trabajo, razón, and idea
description: The most common Spanish nouns aren’t physical objects — they’re abstract ideas, such as problema, trabajo, razón, and idea. Let’s learn and practice several Spanish abstract nouns.

title: 65: Practice Hacer
description: Let’s get some good spoken practice with all the conjugations of Hacer, along with all the other Spanish we’ve learned recently on the podcast. Try to answer all the quiz questions out loud!

title: 66: Poder
description: How do you say “can” in Spanish? Today we’ll explore the verb Poder and start using it to say “can”, “can’t”, and “might” in Spanish.

title: 67: How to say “could” in Spanish
description: Let’s learn the rest of the essential conjugations of Poder, including the past tense, the future tense, and the subjunctive, so that we can say “was able”, “will be able”, “would be able”, and “could”.

title: 68: Spanish adjectives: Feliz, mismo, seguro
description: Today we’ll learn some Spanish adjectives, including feliz, mismo, seguro, and claro. These are very frequent adjectives that you’ll encounter in just about every Spanish conversation.

title: 69: Hora, minuto, semana, y mes
description: Spanish has a lot of nouns for time. Let’s learn the words for “hour”, “minute”, “week”, “month”, and many more. We’ll also learn how to talk about clock time in Spanish, such as how to say “one o’clock” or “three o’clock”.

title: 70: Practice Poder
description: Let’spractice saying things like “can”, “can’t”, “could”, and “couldn’t” in Spanish, in real-life conte xts. Quiz and speak along.

title: 71: Querer: “want” and “love”
description: Let’s learn the Spanish verb Querer, which means “to want” and “to love”. We’ll practice using the unconjugated forms (querer and querido), along with all the present-tense forms (quiero, quiere, quieres, quieren, and queremos).

title: 72: Spanish for “loved” and “wanted”
description: Let’s conjugate Querer in the past! We’ll learn how to say “wanted”, “loved”, and a version of the word “meant” in Spanish. We’ll also work on Querer’s many subjunctive forms, which are more common than you might expect.

title: 73: Spanish adjectives: Nuevo, menos, muerto, vivo
description: Let’s learn some essential Spanish adjectives, such as nuevo, menos, muerto, and vivo. We’ll get lots of practice with these, including the nuances of when to use adjectives with Ser versus with Estar.

title: 74: Nombre, tipo, historia, and other Spanish abstract nouns
description: Let’s practice some common Spanish abstract nouns, including nombre, tipo, historia, and poco.

title: 75: Practice Querer out loud
description: In this episode we’ll practice the verb Querer, in all of its essential conjugations, with an extensive quiz. Practice along out loud!

title: 76: Saber
description: The Spanish verb Saber means “to know”. Let’s learn saber, sabido, sé, sabe, sabes, saben, and sabemos. We’ll also get lots of practice using this verb out loud.

title: 77: Supe, sabrá, haya, and hubiera
description: Let’s learn the rest of our conjugations of Saber, as well as a few new conjugations of Haber, including the subjunctive and the preterite.

title: 78: Desde, sin, sobre, and hace
description: Let’s learn the last of our essential pronouns, including sin, sobre, desde, hace, and contra. We’ll also practice the possessive pronouns mío, tuyo, and suyo.

title: 79: How to talk about family in Spanish
description: Let’s learn the most common Spanish words for family members, including, “brother”, “sister”, “mother”, and “father”. We’ll also get lots of spoken practice with all these words.

title: 80: Practice Saber
description: Let’s get lots of spoken practice with the Spanish verb Saber, in all its conjugations and nuanced uses!

title: 81: Decir
description: Let’s learn the Spanish verb Decir, which means “to say” or “to tell”. We’ll get lots of practice using Decir out loud in a variety of sentences, with both direct and indirect objects!

title: 82: Decir in the past
description: Let’s conjugate Decir in the past, as well as learn Decir’s imperatives, so that we can say things like “I said it”, “she will say something”, and “tell him this”.

title: 83: Hoy, mañana, ayer
description: Let’s learn some adverbs related to time, including the words for “today”, “tomorrow”, “yesterday”, and “still”.

title: 84: Ayuda, camino, pregunta
description: Let’s learn some abstract nouns in Spanish, including the words for “question”, “help”, and “opportunity”.

title: 85: Practice using the Spanish verb Decir
description: Here’s a quiz to practice Decir, out loud, in a wide variety of sentence contexts.

title: 86: Dar
description: The Spanish verb Dar means “to give”. Let’s practice the present tense and unconjugated forms (dar, dado, and dando).

title: 87: Di, dio, daré
description: Let’s keep working on Dar — we’ll practice the preterite (di, dio, dieron, etc.) as well as the subjunctive forms, imperatives, and contractions.

title: 88: Aunque, cual, pues
description: Spanish connecting words can be tricky, but we’ll get lots of practice with them in today’s episode! Let’s work on the words aunque, cual, pues, mientras, and several others, and quiz them in lots of spoken practice.

title: 89: Cuerpo, manos, ojos, and cabeza
description: Let’s learn some body parts in Spanish! The most commonly mention parts of the body include “hands”, “head”, “heart”, “eyes”. Let’s learn these and several more Spanish nouns, and we’ll also get lots of spoken practice with them in context.

title: 90: Practice Dar
description: Practice the Spanish verb Dar out loud, in a variety of sentence contexts, by speaking along with today’s episode.

title: 91: Poner
description: Let’s work on the verb Poner, which means “to put”, and Ponerse, which can be used in a variety of ways. We’ll get lots of spoken practice with poner, puesto, pongo, pone, pones, ponen, and ponemos.

title: 92: ¡Ponte feliz!
description: Let’s keep working on Poner and Ponerse. We’ll practice the preterite (puse, puso, pusiste, etc.) as well as the subjunctive forms, imperatives, and contractions.

title: 93: Casi, igual, quizás, and other Spanish adverbs
description: There are a lot of Spanish adverbs that talk about whether or not something is true — or whether it *might* be true. Let’s learn words for “maybe”, “almost”, “really”, and several more.

title: 94: Clase, paz, amor, and Suponer
description: Let’s learn how to say “I guess” in Spanish, as well as several essential nouns, including the words for “class”, “love”, “fear”, and “peace.

title: 95: Practice Poner and Suponer
description: Let’s practice Poner and Suponer, including Suponerse and the idiom por supuesto, using a big quiz. Speak along to practice out loud!

title: 96: Ver
description: How do you talk about “seeing” things in Spanish? Let’s learn the verb Ver and all of its essential conjugations, so we can say things like “I see”, “they saw”, and “let’s see”.

title: 97: Venir
description: The Spanish verb Venir means “to come”. Let’s learn Venir and all of its essential conjugations, so we can say things like “come here”, “they came yesterday”, and “she wants to come to my party”.

title: 98: Indefinite Adjectives
description: Alguno, ninguno, suficiente, demasiado… let’s learn and practice Spanish indefinite adjectives so that we can say things like “some”, “none”, “enough”, “too much”, and “each”.

title: 99: Agua, dinero, auto
description: Let’s learn some fun Spanish nouns, including words for “water”, “money”, “car”, and “light”. We’ll also get lots of good spoken practice with these new words.

title: 100: No more Spanglish!
description: Let’s practice our Spanish, including our new verbs Ver and Venir and our new nouns. All of today’s sentence examples will be entirely in Spanish, as will all of our Spanish practice on the rest of this podcast!

title: 101: Hablar
description: Hablar is the Spanish verb for “to speak” or “to talk”. Let’s learn Hablar and all of its conjugations, including the present, past, future, and subjunctive. We’ll also get lots of practice using Hablar in real sentence contexts.

title: 102: Pasar
description: The Spanish verb Pasar means “to pass” or “to happen”. This verb is conjugated exactly like Hablar, yesterday’s verb. Let’s learn all about Pasar and get lots of practice using it in context.

title: 103: Spanish Interjections
description: How do you say “um” in Spanish? Or how about “yikes” or “all right”? Let’s learn some of the most common Spanish interjections and get practice using them in context!

title: 104: Fin, muerte, número, and other nouns
description: Let’s learn the Spanish nouns for “end”, “ending”, “number”, “couple”, and many others. We’ll also get lots of spoken practice putting these new nouns in real sentences.

title: 105: Practice Hablar and Pasar
description: Let’s use a quiz to get lots of spoken practice with Hablar, Pasar, and everything else we learned this week.

title: 106: Deber and regular ER verbs
description: Let’s start learning the verb Deber, which means *something* like “must”. This verb will also help us conjugate regular verbs that end with ER, so this episode lays a great foundation for conjugating lots more verbs!

title: 107: How to say “should” in Spanish
description: How do you say “should” in Spanish? Let’s keep working on the verb Deber, and we’ll learn how to use forms like debería to say “should”, “shouldn’t”, and things like that.

title: 108: Allí, allá, arriba, and adelante
description: Why does Spanish have three different words that mean “there”? Let’s explore a bunch of Spanish adverbs that reference location, including allí, allá, arriba, adelante, and atrás.

title: 109: Calle, pueblo, ciudad, mundo
description: Let’s learn Spanish nouns for locations, including the words for “street”, “town”, “city”, and “world”.

title: 110: Practice Deber
description: Let’s practice Deber out loud using a big quiz that covers everything we’ve learned this week.

title: 111: Dejar
description: The Spanish verb Dejar means a variety of things, including “to leave” and “to let”. Let’s learn this verb’s common forms and practice it in a variety of real-life Spanish sentences.

title: 112: Esperar
description: Let’s learn the Spanish verb Esperar so that we can talk about “hoping” and “waiting” in Spanish. Speak along to get lots of out-loud practice with the verb Esperar!

title: 113: More Essential Spanish Adverbs
description: Let’s learn more essential Spanish adverbs, including peor, rápido, and primero. We’ll also get lots of practice using these adverbs in real-life sentence contexts.

title: 114: Juego, realidad, lista, and other nouns
description: Let’s learn some more important Spanish nouns! Today we’ll learn the words for “game”, “reality”, “safety”, and “list”, among others. We’ll also learn and practice some new idioms.

title: 115: Practice Dejar and Esperar
description: Let’s use a quiz to practice everything we’ve been learning this week, including the verbs Dejar and Esperar, as well as all of our new adverbs, nouns, and idioms.

title: 116: Creer
description: The Spanish verb “creer” means “to believe”, or in some cases, “to think”. Let’s practice Creer and all of its essential conjugations.

title: 117: Pensar
description: How do you say “think” in Spanish? Is it Pensar or Creer? Let’s discuss these two verbs so that we can properly translate “think” from English into Spanish.

title: 118: Adjectives that use Ser and Estar
description: Some Spanish adjectives go with Estar, some go with Ser. And some go with both, but they change meanings based on the verb! Let’s discuss the adjectives listo, claro, alto, and others, and get lots of practice using them with both Ser and Estar.

title: 119: Perro, café, and teléfono
description: Let’s learn some fun nouns for physical items, including the words for “bed”, “fire”, “coffee”, “telephone”, and “dog”.

title: 120: Practice Pensar and Creer
description: Let’s get lots of practice with Pensar, Creer, and everything else we’ve learned this week. Speak along out loud!

title: 121: Necesitar and Mirar
description: What’s the difference between Mirar and Ver? And how do you know whether to use Necesitar, Deber, or Tener Que? Let’s practice these verbs in real Spanish sentences.

title: 122: Vivir
description: Let’s learn and practice Vivir, the Spanish verb for “to live”. This is our first regular verb ending in I-R, so it’s going to help us conjugate lots of other verbs going forward!

title: 123: Cuatro, cinco, seis, and siete
description: Let’s continue learning Spanish numbers! After this episode, you’ll know how to count to seven in Spanish. We’ll also get some good listening comprehension practice so that you can identify Spanish numbers when you hear them.

title: 124: How to say “o’clock” in Spanish
description: Let’s learn some new Spanish nouns and idioms, including the idioms for “o’clock”, “in the first place”, and “that makes sense”.

title: 125: Practice Vivir, Mirar, and Necesitar
description: Let’s practice the verbs Vivir, Mirar, and Necesitar, along with everything else we’ve learned this week, using a quiz. Speak out loud to practice!

title: 126: Gustar
description: Let’s learn how to say “like” in Spanish. The verb Gustar works very differently in Spanish from the verb “like” in English, but after this episode, you’ll be a master at using it with indirect objects.

title: 127: Preocupar and Preocuparse
description: Don’t worry! After this episode you’ll know how to talk about worrying in Spanish. Let’s practice the Spanish verbs Preocupar and Preocuparse, and we’ll get lots of spoken practice using these verbs in real-life Spanish sentence contexts.

title: 128: Joven y Viejo
description: Let’s learn the Spanish adjectives for “young”, “old”, “important”, “together”, “bad”, and “awesome”. We’ll get lots of spoken practice using these adjectives in real-life Spanish sentences.

title: 129: Maestro vs Profesor
description: How do you say “teacher” in Spanish? Let’s learn the difference between maestro and profesor. We’ll also learn some other fun nouns for titles, including rey, presidente, and jefe.

title: 130: Practice Gustar Out Loud
description: Here’s a spoken quiz to practice Gustar in real-life sentences, along with the other affective verbs Importar and Preocupar.

title: 131: Llamar and Parecer
description: Let’s learn the Spanish verbs for “call” and “seem”. We’ll get lots of practice with all the common uses of Llamar, Llamarse, and Parecer.

title: 132: Salir
description: The verb Salir means “to exit”, “to go out”, or “to come out”. Let’s get lots of practice with the various uses of this versatile verb.

title: 133: How to add and subtract in Spanish
description: How do you say “plus” and “minus” in Spanish? Today we’ll finish learning how to count to ten, plus we’ll learn how to do math in Spanish so that we can say things like “two plus seven equals nine”.

title: 134: Control, trato, and de hecho
description: Let’s learn a few new abstract nouns in Spanish, including the words for “control”, “deal”, “treatment”, and “fact”. We’ll get lots of spoken practice with these new words and some related idioms.

title: 135: Practice Parecer, Salir, and Llamar
description: Let’s get lots of spoken practice with verbs Parecer, Salir, and Llamar, as well as our new numbers and everything else we’ve learned this week. Predict the Spanish and speak out loud!

title: 136: Oír
description: Let’s learn the Spanish verb Oír, which means “to hear”. We’ll also learn why this verb is sometimes used to say “hey!” in Spanish, and we’ll get lots of practice using Oír in real-life Spanish sentences.

title: 137: Escuchar vs Oír
description: What’s the difference between Escuchar and Oír in Spanish? Let’s learn the Spanish verb for “listen” and learn how to choose between Escuchar and Oír. We’ll also learn the Spanish verb for “work”.

title: 138: Fácil, difícil
description: Let’s learn some new adjectives in Spanish, including the words for “easy”, “difficult”, and “strong”.

title: 139: Tren, barco, avión
description: Let’s learn some fun nouns in Spanish, including the words for “train”, “boat”, “airplane”, “movie”, and “photo”. We’ll get lots of practice using these nouns in real Spanish sentences.

title: 140: Practice Oír and Escuchar
description: Let’s practice the verbs Oír and Escuchar, as well as everything else we’ve learned this week, using a big quiz. Try to predict the Spanish, and make sure to practice out loud!

title: 141: Morir
description: Let’s learn the verb Morir, the Spanish verb for “to die”, including all of its commonly used conjugations, and get lots of practice using it in real sentence contexts.

title: 142: Entender
description: The verb Entender mean “to understand”. Let’s practice using this verb in a variety of contexts, including all its common conjugations.

title: 143: Once, doce, trece, catorce, quince
description: Let’s learn how to count to fifteen in Spanish! We’ll learn the Spanish words for eleven, twelve, thirteen, fourteen, and fifteen, and we’ll get lots of practice using all of our numbers in real-life Spanish sentences.

title: 144: Sueño, orden, falta
description: Let’s learn some new nouns in Spanish, including the words for “dream”, “order”, “lack, and “curse”. We’ll get lots of spoken practice with these new words and some related idioms.

title: 145: Practice Entender and Morir
description: Let’s get lots of spoken practice with verbs Entender and Morir, as well as our new nouns and everything else we’ve learned this week. Predict the Spanish and speak out loud!

title: 146: Sentir and Sentirse
description: Today we’ll learn the verb Sentir, which is how you say “feel” in Spanish. We’ll also explore Sentirse and how it is different from Sentir, and we’ll get lots of spoken practice in real sentence contexts. Practice along out loud!

title: 147: Sentar and Sentarse
description: Today we’ll learn how to say “sit” or “sit down” in Spanish, and we’ll get lots of spoken practice using Sentar (and Sentarse) in real sentence contexts.

title: 148: “Right” in Spanish: Correcto, derecha, derecho
description: How do you say “right” in Spanish? Is it “derecha”, “derecho”, or “correcto”? Today we’ll explore a bunch of important adjectives in Spanish, and we’ll get lots of practice choosing the right one.

title: 149: Damas y caballeros
description: Today we’re going to learn some new nouns to describe people, including some religious words such as “God”, “devil”, and “saint”, as well as how to say “ladies and gentlemen” in Spanish!

title: 150: Practice Sentir and Sentar
description: Let’s use a big spoken Spanish quiz to practice the verbs Sentir, Sentar, Sentirse, and Sentarse, along with everything else we’ve learned this week!

title: 151: Volver
description: The Spanish verb Volver means “to go back”, “to come back”, or to do something again. Let’s explore this complex verb and get lots of verbal practice!

title: 152: Llegar, Buscar
description: Let’s learn two new regular Spanish verbs, Llegar and Buscar. We’ll learn how to use these verbs in all kinds of contexts, in all their common forms, and we’ll get lots of spoken practice.

title: 153: How To Count to Twenty in Spanish
description: Time for more Spanish numbers! Let’s learn the Spanish words for sixteen, seventeen, eighteen, nineteen, and twenty. We’ll lots of practice using and comprehending these numbers in real-life contexts.

title: 154: Media vs mitad
description: How do you say “half” in Spanish? Let’s explore some Spanish nouns that mean “half”, “middle”, and “average”, as well as various other descriptions of amounts and parts.

title: 155: Practice Volver, Llegar, and Buscar
description: Let’s use a quiz to get lots of practice with the verbs Volver, Llegar, and Buscar, as well as everything else we’ve learned this week. Try to predict the Spanish, and speak out loud!

title: 156: How to say “take” in Spanish
description: What’s the difference between Tomar and Llevar in Spanish? Let’s learn these two verbs that both mean “take” but are used in different ways. We’ll get a variety of practice using these new verbs in a variety of Spanish sentences.

title: 157: Conocer vs Saber
description: Why does Spanish have two different verbs that mean “know”? And how do you know whether to use Saber or Conocer? Let’s explore these two verbs and practice using them in lots of real sentence contexts.

title: 158: Lindo, bonito, hermoso, bello
description: What’s the difference in Spanish between lindo, bonito, and hermoso? Let’s learn a bunch of new Spanish adjectives, including the words for “beautiful”, “important”, “strange”, and “funny”.

title: 159: Edificio, oficina, baño
description: Today we’re going to learn some new nouns to describe places, including the words for “building”, “office”, “bathroom”, and “countryside”. We’ll also get a variety of practice with these new nouns in a variety of Spanish sentences.

title: 160: Practice Tomar and Llevar
description: Let’s practice the verbs Tomar and Llevar, as well as everything else we’ve learned this week, using a big quiz. Try to predict the Spanish, and make sure to practice out loud!

title: 161: Tratar
description: Let’s learn the verb Tratar, the Spanish verb for “to try” or “to treat”, including all of its commonly used conjugations. We’ll also get lots of practice using Tratar and Tratarse in real sentence contexts.

title: 162: Acabar
description: The Spanish verb Acabar means something like “to have just done” something. Let’s practice using this strange verb in a variety of contexts, including all its common conjugations.

title: 163: Veintiuno, veintidós, veintitrés
description: Let’s learn how to count to twenty-nine in Spanish! We’ll learn the Spanish words for twenty-one, twenty-two, and so on, and we’ll get lots of practice using all of our numbers in real-life Spanish sentences.

title: 164: Norte, sur, este, oeste
description: Let’s learn some new nouns in Spanish, including the words for “north”, “south”, “front”, and “corner”. We’ll get lots of spoken practice with these new words.

title: 165: Practice Tratar and Acabar
description: Let’s get lots of spoken practice with verbs Tratar and Acabar, as well as our new nouns, numbers, and everything else we’ve learned this week. Predict the Spanish and speak out loud!

title: 166: Seguir
description: Today we’ll learn the verb Seguir, which is a complex Spanish verb that can mean ”to follow”, “to continue”, or “to keep” doing something. We’ll get lots of spoken practice with Seguir in real sentence contexts. Practice along out loud!

title: 167: Terminar vs. Acabar
description: Why does Spanish have two verbs that mean “to finish”? Today we’ll explore the verb Terminar and how it’s used differently from Acabar. We’ll also get lots of spoken practice using Terminar in real sentence contexts.

title: 168: Blanco y negro
description: How do you say “free” in Spanish? Is it “libre” or “gratis”? Today we’ll explore a bunch of new adjectives in Spanish, including the words for “free”, “incredible”, “white”, and “black”.

title: 169: Abuelo, abuela, tío, novia
description: Today we’re going to learn some new nouns to describe people, including family members such as “grandfather”, “grandmother”, “uncle”, and “aunt”.

title: 170: Practice Seguir and Terminar
description: Let’s use a big spoken Spanish quiz to practice the verbs Seguir and Terminar, along with everything else we’ve learned this week!

title: 171: Encontrar and Recordar
description: Encontrar and Recordar are two Spanish verbs that are frequently used but are slightly irregular. Let’s explore both of these verbs and get lots of verbal practice!

title: 172: Entrar and Matar
description: Let’s learn two new regular Spanish verbs, Entrar and Matar. We’ll learn how to use these verbs in all kinds of contexts, in all their common forms, and we’ll get lots of spoken practice.

title: 173: Spanish Colors and Numbers
description: Let’s learn how to talk about some colors in Spanish! We’ll learn the Spanish words for “red”, “blue”, and “green”. We’ll also learn more numbers so that we can count to 39 in Spanish.

title: 174: Información
description: How do you talk about messages and information in Spanish? Let’s learn some new Spanish nouns, including the words for “message”, “information”, and “attention”.

title: 175: Practice Encontrar and Recordar
description: Let’s use a quiz to get lots of practice with the verbs Encontrar, Recordar, Entrar, and Matar, as well as everything else we’ve learned this week. Try to predict the Spanish, and speak out loud!

title: 176: Perder and Perderse
description: Let’s explore the Spanish verb for “to lose” and “to get lost”. We’ll get a lot of practice using Perder and Perderse in a variety of Spanish sentences.

title: 177: Comer and Suceder
description: Let’s explore two new regular Spanish verbs, Comer, which means “to eat”, and Suceder, which means “to happen” or “to occur”. We’ll get lots of practice using them in a variety of real sentence contexts.

title: 178: Encima vs Además
description: What’s the difference in Spanish between encima and además? Let’s learn a bunch of new Spanish adverbs, including the words for “besides”, “around”, and “including”.

title: 179: Hambre, frío, and other feelings
description: In Spanish, are you “hungry” or do you “have hunger”? Let’s explore a bunch of Spanish nouns that can describe how you feel, including words for pain, pleasure, and pity. We’ll also get a variety of practice with these new nouns in a variety of Spanish sentences.

title: 180: Practice Perder and Suceder
description: Let’s practice the verbs Perder, Comer, and Suceder, as well as everything else we’ve learned this week, using a big quiz. Try to predict the Spanish, and make sure to practice out loud!

title: 181: Disculpar, Ayudar, Significar
description: Let’s learn the verbs Disculpar, Ayudar, and Significar, including all of their commonly used conjugations. We’ll also get lots of practice using all these verbs in real sentence contexts.

title: 182: Jugar
description: The Spanish verb Jugar is one way to translate the English verb “play”. Let’s practice using this slightly irregular verb in a variety of contexts, including all its common conjugations.

title: 183: Cuarenta y Cincuenta
description: Let’s learn how to count to fifty-nine in Spanish! We’ll learn the Spanish words for forty and fifty, and we’ll get lots of practice using all of our numbers in real-life Spanish sentences.

title: 184: Noticia, decisión, respuesta
description: Let’s learn some new nouns in Spanish, including the words for “news”, “decision”, “answer”, and “appointment”. We’ll get lots of spoken practice with these new words.

title: 185: Practice Jugar and Disculpar
description: Let’s get lots of spoken practice with verbs Jugar, Significar, Ayudar, and Disculpar, as well as our new nouns, numbers, and everything else we’ve learned this week. Predict the Spanish and speak out loud!

title: 186: Preguntar
description: Today we’ll learn the verb Preguntar, which means “to ask”, as well as Preguntarse, which means “to wonder”. We’ll get lots of spoken practice with both Preguntar and Preguntarse in real sentence contexts. Practice along out loud!

title: 187: Preguntar vs. Pedir
description: Why does Spanish have two verbs that mean “to ask”? Today we’ll explore the verb Pedir and how it’s used differently from Preguntar. We’ll also get lots of spoken practice using both Pedir and Preguntar in real sentence contexts.

title: 188: Próximo vs Siguiente
description: What’s the difference in Spanish between próximo and siguiente? Let’s learn a bunch of new Spanish adjectives, including the words for “next”, “different”, and “normal”.

title: 189: Silla, asiento, banco
description: Today we’re going to learn some fun new nouns for physical items, including the words for “chair”, “box”, “cash”, and “salt”. We’ll also get some spoken practice quizzing with these new words in lots of different contexts.

title: 190: Practice Preguntar and Pedir
description: Let’s use a big spoken Spanish quiz to practice the verbs Preguntar and Pedir, along with our new nouns and everything else we’ve learned this week!

title: 191: Contar
description: The Spanish verb Contar is very frequently used, and it means more than one thing. Let’s learn how to talk about counting, and about telling stories, in Spanish.

title: 192: Valer
description: Let’s learn the Spanish verb Valer. We’ll look at how it’s used in all kinds of contexts, in all its common forms, and we’ll get lots of spoken practice.

title: 193: The 60s and 70s
description: Let’s learn how to count to 79 in Spanish! We’ll also learn some new ways to use numbers, including how to say “the sixties” and “the seventies” in Spanish.

title: 194: Fuerza, ley, programa
description: Let’s learn several new abstract nouns in Spanish, including the words for “force”, “silence”, “program”, and “law”.

title: 195: Practice Contar and Valer
description: Let’s use a quiz to get lots of practice with the verbs Contar and Valer, as well as our new numbers and everything else we’ve learned this week. Try to predict the Spanish, and speak out loud!

title: 196: Quedar and Quedarse
description: Quedar is a common Spanish verb with many different uses. Let’s explore the many different meanings of Quedar and Quedarse. We’ll get lots of spoken practice with this verb in all its common forms.

title: 197: Cambiar
description: Let’s explore a new regular Spanish verb, Cambiar, which means “to change”. We’ll get lots of practice using Cambiar and Cambiarse in a variety of real sentence contexts.

title: 198: Ello vs Eso
description: What does “ello” mean in Spanish? Why don’t we just use “eso”? Let’s explore this strange pronoun and how it helps make Spanish so different from English.

title: 199: Carta vs. Tarjeta
description: Why does Spanish have two different words for “card”? And how do you know which one to use? Let’s explore the words carta and tarjeta. We’ll also learn some other fun Spanish nouns, including the words for “camera”, “company”, and “gift”.

title: 200: Practice Quedar and Cambiar
description: Let’s practice the verbs Quedar, Quedarse, and Cambiar, as well as everything else we’ve learned this week, using a big quiz. Try to predict the Spanish, and make sure to practice out loud!

title: 201: Andar, Part 1
description: Let’s start learning Andar, a very tricky Spanish verb with lots of different meanings. We’ll learn the present-tense conjugations and all the most common uses, and we’ll practice in a variety of sentence contexts.

title: 202: Andar and Regresar
description: Let’s learn the Spanish verb Regresar, which roughly means “to return” We’ll also keep working on the Spanish verb Andar, and we’ll practice both verbs in all of their most common forms and uses.

title: 203: Count to 99 in Spanish
description: Let’s learn the rest of our Spanish numbers from 80 to 99! We’ll learn the Spanish words for eighty and ninety, and we’ll get lots of practice using our numbers in real-life Spanish sentences.

title: 204: Proyecto, accidente, sorpresa
description: Let’s learn some new nouns in Spanish, including the words for “project”, “mission”, “accident”, and “surprise”. We’ll get lots of spoken practice with these new words.

title: 205: Practice Andar and Regresar
description: Let’s get lots of spoken practice with verbs Andar and Regresar, as well as our new nouns, numbers, and everything else we’ve learned this week. Predict the Spanish and speak out loud!

title: 206: Ocurrir and Dormir
description: Today we’ll learn the verb Ocurrir, which means something like “to occur”, as well as Dormir, which means “to sleep”. We’ll get lots of spoken practice with both Ocurrir and Dormir in real sentence contexts. Practice along out loud!

title: 207: Casar vs Casarse, Amar vs Querer
description: How do you say “marry” in Spanish? And why does Spanish have two verbs that mean “to love”? Today we’ll explore the verb Casarse, as well as Amar, and what the difference is between Amar and Querer. We’ll also get lots of spoken practice using both Casarse and Amar in real sentence contexts.

title: 208: Ser and Estar, Advanced Uses
description: Can you ever say “es feliz” or “está bueno” in Spanish? And what do phrases like “fue hecha” mean? Let’s go through some advanced uses of Ser and Estar. We’ll get lots of spoken practice with these nuances in real-life Spanish sentences.

title: 209: El cuerpo y la salud
description: Today we’re going to learn some new nouns for things related to health and the human body, including the words for “medicine”, “nurse”, “ears”, and “nose”. We’ll also get some spoken practice quizzing with these new words in lots of different contexts.

title: 210: Practice advanced uses of Ser and Estar
description: Let’s use a big spoken Spanish quiz to practice our new, advanced uses of Ser and Estar, along with our new nouns and everything else we’ve learned this week!

title: 211: Faltar and Callar
description: Why is the verb Faltar, which means “to lack”, so common in Spanish but not in English? And what’s the difference between Faltar and Hacerle Falta? Let’s learn how to use Faltar, and we’ll also talk about the frequently-used (but sometimes impolite) verb Callarse.

title: 212: Temer, Pelear
description: What’s the difference between Temer and Tener miedo? Let’s learn how to talk about “fearing” and “being afraid” in Spanish. We’ll also practice the verb Pelear, which means “to fight”.

title: 213: Cien vs ciento vs cientos
description: Let’s learn how to count to 999 in Spanish! We’ll learn the words for one hundred, two hundred, three hundred, and so on. We’ll also learn some other things you can do with the words cien, ciento, and cientos in Spanish.

title: 214: Color, tamaño, posición
description: Let’s learn several new abstract nouns in Spanish, including the words for “color”, “size”, “position”, and “example”. We’ll get lots of spoken practice with these common nouns in real sentence contexts.

title: 215: Practice Faltar and Temer
description: Let’s use a quiz to get lots of practice with the verbs Faltar and Temer, as well as our new numbers and everything else we’ve learned this week. Try to predict the Spanish, and speak out loud!

title: 216: Empezar and Probar
description: What’s the difference between Probar and Tratar? And how do you say “start” in Spanish? Let’s explore these essential Spanish verbs. We’ll get lots of spoken practice in all of the common forms of Empezar and Probar.

title: 217: Salvar, Odiar, Lamentar
description: Let’s explore three new regular Spanish verbs: Salvar, Odiar, and Lamentar. We’ll get lots of practice using these verbs in a variety of real sentence contexts.

title: 218: Sino vs Pero
description: What does “sino” mean in Spanish? Why don’t we just use “pero”? Let’s explore this interesting conjunction and how it helps make Spanish so different from English.

title: 219: La Naturaleza
description: Let’s learn several new Spanish nouns that are often found outdoors, including the words “plant”, “nature”, “tree”, “sun”, and “river”. We’ll also get some spoken practice quizzing with these new words in lots of different contexts.

title: 220: Practice Empezar and Probar
description: Let’s practice the verbs Empezar and Probar, as well as everything else we’ve learned this week, using a big quiz. Try to predict the Spanish, and make sure to practice out loud!

title: 221: Sonar, Doler, Tocar
description: Let’s learn the Spanish verb Sonar, which roughly means “to sound”, Doler, which roughly means “to hurt”, and Tocar, which roughly means “to touch”. We’ll practice all three verbs in all of their most common forms and uses.

title: 222: Gustar vs Encantar vs Amar
description: Let’s learn the verbs Encantar and Bastar, which are two important Spanish verbs that wor learning Andar. We’ll practice these new Spanish “affective” verbs in a variety of sentence contexts.

title: 223: Hablando de millones
description: Let’s learn the rest of our Spanish numbers into the millions! We’ll learn the Spanish words for “thousand” and “million”, and we’ll get lots of practice using our numbers in real-life Spanish sentences. We’ll also learn some new things about Spanish gerunds.

title: 224: Las Vacaciones
description: Let’s learn some new nouns you can use to describe people, including the words for “detective”, “captain”, and “role”, as well as some nouns relevant to travel, such as “vacation”, “traffic”, and “flight”.

title: 225: Practice Encantar and Bastar
description: Let’s get lots of spoken practice with verbs Encantar and Bastar, as well as our new nouns, numbers, and everything else we’ve learned this week. Predict the Spanish and speak out loud!

title: 226: How to say “get” in Spanish
description: How do you say “get” in Spanish? Today we’ll explore why there’s no simple translation of “get” from English into Spanish (or any other language!). But we’ll also learn the verb Conseguir, which means “to get” in some contexts, specifically when it means “to acquire”. Practice along out loud!

title: 227: Funcionar vs Trabajar
description: Why does Spanish have two verbs that mean “work”? Today we’ll explore the verb Funcionar and why it’s different from Trabajar. We’ll also get lots of spoken practice using Funcionar in real sentence contexts.

title: 228: Maravilloso, excelente, divertido
description: Today we’ll learn a bunch of new Spanish adjectives, including the words for “wonderful”, “excellent”, and “fun”.

title: 229: Dirección vs Destino
description: Today we’re going to learn some new location nouns, including the words for “direction”, “address”, “destination”, and “area”. We’ll also get some spoken practice quizzing with these new words in lots of different contexts.

title: 230: Practice Conseguir and Funcionar
description: Let’s use a big spoken Spanish quiz to practice Conseguir, Funcionar, Ganar, Pagar and everything else we’ve learned this week!

title: 231: Jurar, Desear
description: Why is the verb Desear, which means “to wish”, more common in Spanish than in English? Let’s learn how to use Desear, and we’ll also talk about the frequently-used verb Jurar.

title: 232: Prometer vs Jurar
description: What’s the difference between Prometer and Jurar? Let’s learn how to talk about “swearing” and “promising” in Spanish.

title: 233: Adverbs Ending with “-mente”
description: Can you turn an English adverb into a Spanish adverb by simply ending it with “mente” instead of “ly”? Let’s talk about some of the nuances of Spanish adverbs that end with -mente, including the “false friends” (or false cognates) that can trip English speakers up, such as últimamente.

title: 234: Llave, computadora, gato, objeto
description: Let’s learn some fun new nouns for physical items, including the words for “computer”, “cat”, and “key”. We’ll get lots of spoken practice with these nouns in real sentence contexts.

title: 235: Practice Jurar and Prometer
description: Let’s use a quiz to get lots of practice with the verbs Jurar and Prometer, as well as our new adverbs, nouns, and everything else we’ve learned this week. Try to predict the Spanish, and speak out loud!

title: 236: Traer vs Llevar vs Tomar
description: What’s the difference between Traer and Llevar? Do both verbs mean “bring”? And what does it have to do with how you say “take” in Spanish? Let’s explore these essential Spanish verbs. We’ll get lots of spoken practice in all of the common forms of Traer.

title: 237: Comprar, Vender, Abrir
description: Let’s explore three new Spanish verbs: Comprar, Vender, and Abrir. We’ll get lots of practice using these verbs in a variety of real sentence contexts.

title: 238: Peligroso, dulce, aburrido
description: Let’s learn a bunch of new adjectives in Spanish, including the words for “dangerous”, “sweet”, “boring”, “open”. and “closed”.

title: 239: Restaurante, Tienda, Biblioteca
description: Let’s learn several new Spanish nouns that represent buildings and businesses, including the words for “restaurant”, “shop”, “library”, “church”, and “market”. We’ll also get some spoken practice quizzing with these new words in lots of different contexts.

title: 240: Practice Traer, Comprar, and Vender
description: Let’s practice the verbs Traer, Comprar, Vender, and Abrir, as well as everything else we’ve learned this week, using a big quiz. Try to predict the Spanish, and make sure to practice out loud!

title: 241: Existir, Extrañar, Soñar
description: Let’s learn the Spanish verb Existir, which means “to exist”, Extrañar, which means “to miss”, and Soñar, which means “to dream”. We’ll practice all three verbs in all of their most common forms and uses.

title: 242: Olvidar, Despertar, Alegrar
description: Let’s learn the verbs Olvidar, which means “to forget”, Despertar, which roughly means “to awaken”, and Alegrar, which roughly means “to rejoice” or “to cheer up”. We’ll practice these new verbs in a variety of sentence contexts.

title: 243: Haberlo, Haberte, Haberme
description: Why does Spanish sometimes use pronoun contractions with Haber? Let’s learn how to use contractions like haberlo and haberte. We’ll get lots of practice with these contractions in real sentence contexts.

title: 244: Los días de la semana y los meses del año
description: Let’s learn some new nouns you can use to talk about time, including the days of the week and the months of the year, as well as how to say things like “Wednesday the 27th” or “Friday the 14th”. We’ll get lots of practice trying to say things like this in real time!

title: 245: Practice Existir and Olvidar
description: Let’s get lots of spoken practice with verbs Existir, Extrañar, Soñar, Olvidar, Despertar, and Alegrar, as well as our new nouns, numbers, and everything else we’ve learned this week. Predict the Spanish and speak out loud!

title: 246: Leer, Escribir, Aprender
description: Let’s learn some Spanish verbs related to reading, writing, and learning! We’ll explore the verbs Leer, Escribir, and Aprender, in a wide variety of uses. Practice along out loud!

title: 247: Desayunar, Almorzar, Cenar, Viajar.
description: Why does Spanish have so many different verbs for eating? Today we’ll talk about “having breakfast”, “having lunch”, and “having dinner” in Spanish. We’ll also explore the verb Viajar, which means “to travel”, and we’ll get lots of spoken practice using these verbs in real sentence contexts.

title: 248: Limpio, sucio, mojado, seco
description: Today we’ll learn a bunch of new Spanish adjectives, including the words for “clean”, “dirty”, “wet”, “dry”, “cold”, and “hot”.

title: 249: Hogar
description: Today we’re going to learn some new nouns for household items, including the words for “home”, “furniture”, “refrigerator”, and “kitchen”. We’ll also get some spoken practice quizzing with these new words in lots of different contexts.

title: 250: Final Spanish Practice!
description: Let’s use a big spoken Spanish quiz to practice Leer, Escribir, Aprender, Viajar, and everything else we’ve learned this week!
